title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.13.5-7 | 23-09-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Vidura actually left the palace not because he was insulted by Duryodhana, but really because he wanted to inquire and acquire the knowledge about this cell, Atma Vidya.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Vidura left the palace not because of Duryodhana's insult, but to seek spiritual knowledge and inquire about Atma Vidya.

segments.key_quote: Uddhava directed Vidura to go to Maitreya Rishi, who was nearby, and inquire from Maitreya Rishi about this knowledge of the cell, Atma Vidya.
segments.summary: Vidura travels on pilgrimage, meets Uddhava, who directs him to Maitreya Rishi for spiritual instruction, respecting Vaishnava etiquette.

segments.key_quote: Vidura came back to the palace simply to deliver Dhritarashtra because he himself, Vidura himself was self realized.
segments.summary: Vidura returns to Hastinapura after receiving instruction, intending to deliver Dhritarashtra, who is living comfortably under Yudhishthira's care, and his return is met with joy.

segments.key_quote: Even an enemy received at home should be so well received that he will not feel any fearful situation.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the Vedic culture of hospitality, emphasizing that even enemies should be treated with respect and kindness when they are guests.

segments.key_quote: Even if a stranger enters your house, you will receive him in such a friendly way that he will forget that you are his enemy and he will have no fear.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the Vedic principle of treating uninvited guests (Atithi) with utmost respect and friendliness, ensuring they feel safe and welcome.

segments.key_quote: The Vedic culture is to receive any uninvited guest properly even if the guest happens to be an enemy.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Parikshit Maharaj and Shamika Rishi to illustrate the importance of properly receiving guests, even if they are superiors or enemies, according to scriptural injunctions.
